text:
I just did something I’m proud of: implement an algorithm for an arbitrary-term polynomial regression!

Edit: I should note that it’s more like a script, with the only even slightly technically impressive portion being a translation of some data types based on code someone else found for me online.  The curve fitting is all done in MLJ.jl and data held in DataFrames.jl.  The packages do all the heavy lifting—I just found a workaround for the lack of polynomial regression in MLJ.jl.  Wow, I guess it’s nothing to brag about after all.

elements.text: I just did something I’m proud of: implement an algorithm for an arbitrary-term polynomial regression!

The curve fitting is all done in MLJ.jl and data held in DataFrames.jl.  The packages do all the heavy lifting—I just found a workaround for the lack of polynomial regression in MLJ.jl.  Wow, I guess it’s nothing to brag about after all.

text: HELL YEA!!!!! :raised_hands: Nothing beats that feeling of going from ideas, from papers, or data to a final working algo. Congrats!

elements.text: Nothing beats that feeling of going from ideas, from papers, or data to a final working algo. Congrats!

text: <@U0179G7FG4F> It generates a polynomial regression to an arbitrary number of terms.

text: You might want to check out Remez.jl which does minimax polynomials

text: If you're fitting data, it's really bad, but it's great for thing like special functions.

text: Then you don't want it. Minimax polynomials are only what you want if you care about max error, not abs2 error
